awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE: Statistical Thinking in Undergraduate Biology (STUB) Network: A network for coordinating the teaching and assessment of statistical thinking in introductory biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The practice of biology has transitioned over the last two decades to become increasingly reliant on quantitative approaches to drawing conclusions from data. Consequently, an introduction to both descriptive and inferential statistical thinking is now standard practice for the undergraduate biology course "Bio 101" - a course taken by over 1.2 million students in the U.S. annually. Despite the large numbers of students in introductory biology courses, there is a dearth of active discussion about teaching and assessment when integrating statistical thinking into biology courses. Recently, the statistics education community has established guidelines for assessment and instructional best practices when teaching statistics. Furthermore, there is a prominent movement to use modern, computationally-intensive statistical methods (simulation, randomization tests, and bootstrapping) that utilize active learning pedagogical strategies and have preliminary evidence of improving student learning. Despite these recent changes, there are limited venues to discuss and coordinate best practices for the teaching and assessment of statistical thinking for biology students - many of whom may never take an Introductory Statistics course or will take such a course at a very different time than their introductory biology course. To address these challenges, the Statistical Thinking in Undergraduate Biology (STUB) network will be formed, consisting of over 500 biology and statistics instructors. The network will directly impact over 100,000 students during the five-year period of the award, with many thousands impacted in the following years. With particular focus on a diverse set of institutions, backgrounds, and learning environments (e.g., institutions serving large numbers of underrepresented and underserved students, including two-year colleges), the project has the potential for effecting a substantial change in the content and focus of the teaching of statistical thinking in undergraduate biology across the country.

As part of the network, participants will engage in workshops and an online learning community dedicated to the discussion and sharing of ideas, resources, and techniques. A key tangible outcome of the workshops and online learning community will be freely available, class-tested, and edited modules co-developed by biologists and statisticians for use in teaching statistical ideas. The STUB network will also serve to assist in coordinating the assessment of statistical thinking and student attitudes in introductory biology courses. The network will share best practices on assessment, vet potential assessment items, and share assessment results, as well as evaluate the efficacy of the workshops and the online learning community in improving instructor and student outcomes. The STUB network will provide a forum for serious and impactful discussions about teaching statistics in introductory biology courses, resulting in (a) the development and wide dissemination of numerous freely available modules and assessment items for teaching, (b) published peer-reviewed articles on teaching best practices and assessment results related to statistical thinking in undergraduate biology courses, (c) a long-lasting improvement in the teaching of statistical thinking in the undergraduate biology curriculum, and (d) introductory statistics courses reflecting the needs and perspective of biology (and other quantitative science) students.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO), Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/). This project is also co-funded by the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB) in the BIO directorate and the Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) in the Directorate for Mathematical & Physical Sciences (MPS).

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the National Science Foundation grant Statistical Thinking in Undergraduate Biology (STUB) was to create and support a network of biologists and statisticians to discuss and improve the teaching of statistical thinking in undergraduate biology courses. The primary outcomes of the project include (1) the development of collaborative opportunities between statisticians and biologists to support the use of best practices in teaching statistics within biology courses; (2) the creation of a repository of open-source materials for use in both biology and statistics undergraduate classrooms; (3) preliminary assessment of biology student outcomes and attitudes when encountering statistics ideas in their biology courses; (4) an exploration of methods for conducting and sustaining professional development opportunities for biology instructors teaching statistical thinking.

What follows is a brief description of each of the primary project outcomes.

(1) development of collaborative opportunities between statisticians and biologists to support the use of best practices in teaching statistics within biology courses

Over the course of this project we conducted numerous workshop in a variety of formats – regional, course-focused, in conjunction with biology conferences, in conjunction with statistics conferences, partial day, multi-day, online, in-person, etc. All of these workshops were focused on establishing collaborations between biologists and statisticians to improve the teaching of statistics concepts in biology courses and to enhance the biological applications seen by biology students in their statistics courses.

The final two collaborative opportunities included a 2022-23 academic year project between 6 biologists and 5 statisticians at California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, California and in August/September of 2023 an innovative 3-week largely asynchronous, hands-on professional development workshop for teaching statistics in biology courses.  The Cal Poly academic year project resulted in development and implementation of two lab activities which use regression and chi-square tests. The asynchronous workshop resulted in 25 lessons developed for use in a wide variety of biology courses, incorporating the use of best practices in statistics. These lessons are being implemented in biology courses around the country in academic year 2023-24. Examples of these products are posted at https://www.causeweb.org/stub/.

(2) the creation of a repository of open-source materials for use in both biology and statistics undergraduate classrooms

A sizable amount of effort went into the development of 44 learning modules that can be used in undergraduate statistics courses which utilize best practices in teaching statistics through meaningful biological studies and examples. The modules were developed by the project team and then each was reviewed by a statistician outside the project team and a biologist. The modules were revised to incorporate review suggestions. In addition, eight of the modules were class tested in undergraduate statistics courses. Feedback from the class testing instructors was also incorporated. This suite of modules is open-source and available freely at https://www.causeweb.org/stub/.

(3) preliminary assessment of biology student outcomes and attitudes when encountering statistics ideas in their biology courses

While the primary goals of the STUB network were developing collaborations and content development, assessment was often discussed during workshops and participants were invited to participate in small-scale assessment initiatives. A key preliminary assessment study involving five biology instructors across three institutions has provided initial insights into students’ conceptual understanding and attitudes towards statistics in biology courses (Tintle, McGaughey, Chance, 2022).

(4) an exploration of methods for conducting and sustaining professional development opportunities for biology instructors teaching statistical thinking

An unintended, but very positive outcome of this project came about as a result of the pandemic. Prior to the pandemic, workshops tended to be face-to-face requiring participants to travel. Many were held in conjunction with conferences. In both cases limiting the pool of potential participants. The pandemic necessitated pivoting to online workshops, which ultimately provided the opportunity to reach a broader audience. The project team’s experience and experimentation with methods of conducting online workshops culminated in an innovative, multi-week professional development workshop that was mostly asynchronous. This workshop relied on tools for remote project work, such as Slack, as well as online “office hours” in Zoom. Incorporating a synchronous online kick-off meeting enabled participants to meet and interact with the project leads, as well as each other, and a synchronous closing meeting gave participants the opportunity to report what they learned and accomplished during the workshop. Feedback from workshop participants was positive, both about what they learned and accomplished, as well as the format. The project team believes this format has promise across a broad array of professional development experiences and audiences.
